t: John 1
The Word Became Flesh
In*p the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
He was with God in the beginning.
Through him all things were made; without him nothing was made that has been made.
In him was life, and that life was the light of all mankind.
The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.
There*p was a man sent from God whose name was John.
He came as a witness to testify concerning that light, so that through him all might believe.
He himself was not the light; he came only as a witness to the light.
The*p true light that gives light to everyone was coming into the world.
He was in the world, and though the world was made through him, the world did not recognize him.
He came to that which was his own, but his own did not receive him.
Yet to all who did receive him, to those who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God—
children born not of natural descent, nor of human decision or a husband’s will, but born of God.
The*p Word became flesh and made his dwelling among us. We have seen his glory, the glory of the one and only Son, who came from the Father, full of grace and truth.
(John*p testified concerning him. He cried out, saying, “This is the one I spoke about when I said, ‘He who comes after me has surpassed me because he was before me.’ ”)
Out of his fullness we have all received grace in place of grace already given.
For the law was given through Moses; grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
No one has ever seen God, but the one and only Son, who is himself God and is in closest relationship with the Father, has made him known.
John the Baptist Denies Being the Messiah
Now*p this was John’s testimony when the Jewish leaders in Jerusalem sent priests and Levites to ask him who he was.
He did not fail to confess, but confessed freely, “I am not the Messiah.”
They*p asked him, “Then who are you? Are you Elijah?” He*p said, “I am not.” “Are*p you the Prophet?” He*p answered, “No.”
Finally*p they said, “Who are you? Give us an answer to take back to those who sent us. What do you say about yourself?”
John*p replied in the words of Isaiah the prophet, “I am the voice of one calling in the wilderness, ‘Make straight the way for the Lord.’ ”
Now*p the Pharisees who had been sent
questioned him, “Why then do you baptize if you are not the Messiah, nor Elijah, nor the Prophet?”
“I*p baptize with water,” John replied, “but among you stands one you do not know.
He is the one who comes after me, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie.”
This*p all happened at Bethany on the other side of the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
John Testifies About Jesus
The*p next day John saw Jesus coming toward him and said, “Look, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!
This is the one I meant when I said, ‘A man who comes after me has surpassed me because he was before me.’
I myself did not know him, but the reason I came baptizing with water was that he might be revealed to Israel.”
Then*p John gave this testimony: “I saw the Spirit come down from heaven as a dove and remain on him.
And I myself did not know him, but the one who sent me to baptize with water told me, ‘The man on whom you see the Spirit come down and remain is the one who will baptize with the Holy Spirit.’
I have seen and I testify that this is God’s Chosen One.”
John’s Disciples Follow Jesus
The*p next day John was there again with two of his disciples.
When he saw Jesus passing by, he said, “Look, the Lamb of God!”
When*p the two disciples heard him say this, they followed Jesus.
Turning around, Jesus saw them following and asked, “What*r do*r you*r want?”*r They*p said, “Rabbi” (which means “Teacher”), “where are you staying?”
“Come,”*rp he replied, “and*r you*r will*r see.”*r So*p they went and saw where he was staying, and they spent that day with him. It was about four in the afternoon.
Andrew,*p Simon Peter’s brother, was one of the two who heard what John had said and who had followed Jesus.
The first thing Andrew did was to find his brother Simon and tell him, “We have found the Messiah” (that is, the Christ).
And he brought him to Jesus. Jesus*p looked at him and said, “You*r are*r Simon*r son*r of*r John.*r You*r will*r be*r called*r Cephas”*r (which, when translated, is Peter).
Jesus Calls Philip and Nathanael
The*p next day Jesus decided to leave for Galilee. Finding Philip, he said to him, “Follow*r me.”*r
Philip,*p like Andrew and Peter, was from the town of Bethsaida.
Philip found Nathanael and told him, “We have found the one Moses wrote about in the Law, and about whom the prophets also wrote—Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.”
“Nazareth!*p Can anything good come from there?” Nathanael asked. “Come*p and see,” said Philip.
When*p Jesus saw Nathanael approaching, he said of him, “Here*r truly*r is*r an*r Israelite*r in*r whom*r there*r is*r no*r deceit.”*r
“How*p do you know me?” Nathanael asked. Jesus*p answered, “I*r saw*r you*r while*r you*r were*r still*r under*r the*r fig*r tree*r before*r Philip*r called*r you.”*r
Then*p Nathanael declared, “Rabbi, you are the Son of God; you are the king of Israel.”
Jesus*p said, “You*r believe*r because*r I*r told*r you*r I*r saw*r you*r under*r the*r fig*r tree.*r You*r will*r see*r greater*r things*r than*r that.”*r
He then added, “Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r you*r will*r see*r ‘heaven*r open,*r and*r the*r angels*r of*r God*r ascending*r and*r descending*r on’*r the*r Son*r of*r Man.”*r
John 2
Jesus Changes Water Into Wine
On*p the third day a wedding took place at Cana in Galilee. Jesus’ mother was there,
and Jesus and his disciples had also been invited to the wedding.
When the wine was gone, Jesus’ mother said to him, “They have no more wine.”
“Woman,*rp why*r do*r you*r involve*r me?”*r Jesus replied. “My*r hour*r has*r not*r yet*r come.”*r
His*p mother said to the servants, “Do whatever he tells you.”
Nearby*p stood six stone water jars, the kind used by the Jews for ceremonial washing, each holding from twenty to thirty gallons.
Jesus*p said to the servants, “Fill*r the*r jars*r with*r water”;*r so they filled them to the brim.
Then*p he told them, “Now*r draw*r some*r out*r and*r take*r it*r to*r the*r master*r of*r the*r banquet.”*r They*p did so,

and the master of the banquet tasted the water that had been turned into wine. He did not realize where it had come from, though the servants who had drawn the water knew. Then he called the bridegroom aside
and said, “Everyone brings out the choice wine first and then the cheaper wine after the guests have had too much to drink; but you have saved the best till now.”
What*p Jesus did here in Cana of Galilee was the first of the signs through which he revealed his glory; and his disciples believed in him.
After*p this he went down to Capernaum with his mother and brothers and his disciples. There they stayed for a few days.
Jesus Clears the Temple Courts
When*p it was almost time for the Jewish Passover, Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
In the temple courts he found people selling cattle, sheep and doves, and others sitting at tables exchanging money.
So he made a whip out of cords, and drove all from the temple courts, both sheep and cattle; he scattered the coins of the money changers and overturned their tables.
To those who sold doves he said, “Get*r these*r out*r of*r here!*r Stop*r turning*r my*r Father’s*r house*r into*r a*r market!”*r
His disciples remembered that it is written: “Zeal for your house will consume me.”
The*p Jews then responded to him, “What sign can you show us to prove your authority to do all this?”
Jesus*p answered them, “Destroy*r this*r temple,*r and*r I*r will*r raise*r it*r again*r in*r three*r days.”*r
They*p replied, “It has taken forty-six years to build this temple, and you are going to raise it in three days?”
But the temple he had spoken of was his body.
After he was raised from the dead, his disciples recalled what he had said. Then they believed the scripture and the words that Jesus had spoken.
Now*p while he was in Jerusalem at the Passover Festival, many people saw the signs he was performing and believed in his name.
But Jesus would not entrust himself to them, for he knew all people.
He did not need any testimony about mankind, for he knew what was in each person.
John 3
Jesus Teaches Nicodemus
Now*p there was a Pharisee, a man named Nicodemus who was a member of the Jewish ruling council.
He came to Jesus at night and said, “Rabbi, we know that you are a teacher who has come from God. For no one could perform the signs you are doing if God were not with him.”
Jesus*p replied, “Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r no*r one*r can*r see*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r unless*r they*r are*r born*r again.”*r
“How*p can someone be born when they are old?” Nicodemus asked. “Surely they cannot enter a second time into their mother’s womb to be born!”
Jesus*p answered, “Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r no*r one*r can*r enter*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r unless*r they*r are*r born*r of*r water*r and*r the*r Spirit.*r
Flesh*r gives*r birth*r to*r flesh,*r but*r the*r Spirit*r gives*r birth*r to*r spirit.*r
You*r should*r not*r be*r surprised*r at*r my*r saying,*r ‘You*r must*r be*r born*r again.’*r

The*r wind*r blows*r wherever*r it*r pleases.*r You*r hear*r its*r sound,*r but*r you*r cannot*r tell*r where*r it*r comes*r from*r or*r where*r it*r is*r going.*r So*r it*r is*r with*r everyone*r born*r of*r the*r Spirit.”*r
“How*p can this be?” Nicodemus asked.
“You*rp are*r Israel’s*r teacher,”*r said Jesus, “and*r do*r you*r not*r understand*r these*r things?*r
Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r we*r speak*r of*r what*r we*r know,*r and*r we*r testify*r to*r what*r we*r have*r seen,*r but*r still*r you*r people*r do*r not*r accept*r our*r testimony.*r
I*r have*r spoken*r to*r you*r of*r earthly*r things*r and*r you*r do*r not*r believe;*r how*r then*r will*r you*r believe*r if*r I*r speak*r of*r heavenly*r things?*r
No*r one*r has*r ever*r gone*r into*r heaven*r except*r the*r one*r who*r came*r from*r heaven—the*r Son*r of*r Man.*r
Just*r as*r Moses*r lifted*r up*r the*r snake*r in*r the*r wilderness,*r so*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r must*r be*r lifted*r up,*r
that*r everyone*r who*r believes*r may*r have*r eternal*r life*r in*r him.”*r
For*p God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.
For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but to save the world through him.
Whoever believes in him is not condemned, but whoever does not believe stands condemned already because they have not believed in the name of God’s one and only Son.
This is the verdict: Light has come into the world, but people loved darkness instead of light because their deeds were evil.
Everyone who does evil hates the light, and will not come into the light for fear that their deeds will be exposed.
But whoever lives by the truth comes into the light, so that it may be seen plainly that what they have done has been done in the sight of God.
John Testifies Again About Jesus
After*p this, Jesus and his disciples went out into the Judean countryside, where he spent some time with them, and baptized.
Now John also was baptizing at Aenon near Salim, because there was plenty of water, and people were coming and being baptized.
(This was before John was put in prison.)
An argument developed between some of John’s disciples and a certain Jew over the matter of ceremonial washing.
They came to John and said to him, “Rabbi, that man who was with you on the other side of the Jordan—the one you testified about—look, he is baptizing, and everyone is going to him.”
To*p this John replied, “A person can receive only what is given them from heaven.
You yourselves can testify that I said, ‘I am not the Messiah but am sent ahead of him.’

The bride belongs to the bridegroom. The friend who attends the bridegroom waits and listens for him, and is full of joy when he hears the bridegroom’s voice. That joy is mine, and it is now complete.
He must become greater; I must become less.”
The*p one who comes from above is above all; the one who is from the earth belongs to the earth, and speaks as one from the earth. The one who comes from heaven is above all.
He testifies to what he has seen and heard, but no one accepts his testimony.
Whoever has accepted it has certified that God is truthful.
For the one whom God has sent speaks the words of God, for God gives the Spirit without limit.
The Father loves the Son and has placed everything in his hands.
Whoever believes in the Son has eternal life, but whoever rejects the Son will not see life, for God’s wrath remains on them.
John 4
Jesus Talks With a Samaritan Woman
Now*p Jesus learned that the Pharisees had heard that he was gaining and baptizing more disciples than John—
although in fact it was not Jesus who baptized, but his disciples.
So he left Judea and went back once more to Galilee.
Now*p he had to go through Samaria.
So he came to a town in Samaria called Sychar, near the plot of ground Jacob had given to his son Joseph.
Jacob’s well was there, and Jesus, tired as he was from the journey, sat down by the well. It was about noon.
When*p a Samaritan woman came to draw water, Jesus said to her, “Will*r you*r give*r me*r a*r drink?”*r
(His disciples had gone into the town to buy food.)
The*p Samaritan woman said to him, “You are a Jew and I am a Samaritan woman. How can you ask me for a drink?” (For Jews do not associate with Samaritans.)

Jesus*p answered her, “If*r you*r knew*r the*r gift*r of*r God*r and*r who*r it*r is*r that*r asks*r you*r for*r a*r drink,*r you*r would*r have*r asked*r him*r and*r he*r would*r have*r given*r you*r living*r water.”*r
“Sir,”*p the woman said, “you have nothing to draw with and the well is deep. Where can you get this living water?
Are you greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and drank from it himself, as did also his sons and his livestock?”
Jesus*p answered, “Everyone*r who*r drinks*r this*r water*r will*r be*r thirsty*r again,*r

but*r whoever*r drinks*r the*r water*r I*r give*r them*r will*r never*r thirst.*r Indeed,*r the*r water*r I*r give*r them*r will*r become*r in*r them*r a*r spring*r of*r water*r welling*r up*r to*r eternal*r life.”*r
The*p woman said to him, “Sir, give me this water so that I won’t get thirsty and have to keep coming here to draw water.”
He*p told her, “Go,*r call*r your*r husband*r and*r come*r back.”*r
“I*p have no husband,” she replied. Jesus*p said to her, “You*r are*r right*r when*r you*r say*r you*r have*r no*r husband.*r
The*r fact*r is,*r you*r have*r had*r five*r husbands,*r and*r the*r man*r you*r now*r have*r is*r not*r your*r husband.*r What*r you*r have*r just*r said*r is*r quite*r true.”*r
“Sir,”*p the woman said, “I can see that you are a prophet.
Our ancestors worshiped on this mountain, but you Jews claim that the place where we must worship is in Jerusalem.”
“Woman,”*rp Jesus replied, “believe*r me,*r a*r time*r is*r coming*r when*r you*r will*r worship*r the*r Father*r neither*r on*r this*r mountain*r nor*r in*r Jerusalem.*r
You*r Samaritans*r worship*r what*r you*r do*r not*r know;*r we*r worship*r what*r we*r do*r know,*r for*r salvation*r is*r from*r the*r Jews.*r

Yet*r a*r time*r is*r coming*r and*r has*r now*r come*r when*r the*r true*r worshipers*r will*r worship*r the*r Father*r in*r the*r Spirit*r and*r in*r truth,*r for*r they*r are*r the*r kind*r of*r worshipers*r the*r Father*r seeks.*r
God*r is*r spirit,*r and*r his*r worshipers*r must*r worship*r in*r the*r Spirit*r and*r in*r truth.”*r
The*p woman said, “I know that Messiah” (called Christ) “is coming. When he comes, he will explain everything to us.”
Then*p Jesus declared, “I,*r the*r one*r speaking*r to*r you—I*r am*r he.”*r
The Disciples Rejoin Jesus
Just*p then his disciples returned and were surprised to find him talking with a woman. But no one asked, “What do you want?” or “Why are you talking with her?”
Then,*p leaving her water jar, the woman went back to the town and said to the people,
“Come, see a man who told me everything I ever did. Could this be the Messiah?”
They came out of the town and made their way toward him.
Meanwhile*p his disciples urged him, “Rabbi, eat something.”
But*p he said to them, “I*r have*r food*r to*r eat*r that*r you*r know*r nothing*r about.”*r
Then*p his disciples said to each other, “Could someone have brought him food?”
“My*rp food,”*r said Jesus, “is*r to*r do*r the*r will*r of*r him*r who*r sent*r me*r and*r to*r finish*r his*r work.*r
Don’t*r you*r have*r a*r saying,*r ‘It’s*r still*r four*r months*r until*r harvest’?*r I*r tell*r you,*r open*r your*r eyes*r and*r look*r at*r the*r fields!*r They*r are*r ripe*r for*r harvest.*r
Even*r now*r the*r one*r who*r reaps*r draws*r a*r wage*r and*r harvests*r a*r crop*r for*r eternal*r life,*r so*r that*r the*r sower*r and*r the*r reaper*r may*r be*r glad*r together.*r
Thus*r the*r saying*r ‘One*r sows*r and*r another*r reaps’*r is*r true.*r
I*r sent*r you*r to*r reap*r what*r you*r have*r not*r worked*r for.*r Others*r have*r done*r the*r hard*r work,*r and*r you*r have*r reaped*r the*r benefits*r of*r their*r labor.”*r
Many Samaritans Believe
Many*p of the Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the woman’s testimony, “He told me everything I ever did.”
So when the Samaritans came to him, they urged him to stay with them, and he stayed two days.
And because of his words many more became believers.
They*p said to the woman, “We no longer believe just because of what you said; now we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this man really is the Savior of the world.”
Jesus Heals an Official’s Son
After*p the two days he left for Galilee.
(Now Jesus himself had pointed out that a prophet has no honor in his own country.)
When he arrived in Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him. They had seen all that he had done in Jerusalem at the Passover Festival, for they also had been there.
Once*p more he visited Cana in Galilee, where he had turned the water into wine. And there was a certain royal official whose son lay sick at Capernaum.
When this man heard that Jesus had arrived in Galilee from Judea, he went to him and begged him to come and heal his son, who was close to death.
“Unless*rp you*r people*r see*r signs*r and*r wonders,”*r Jesus told him, “you*r will*r never*r believe.”*r
The*p royal official said, “Sir, come down before my child dies.”
“Go,”*rp Jesus replied, “your*r son*r will*r live.”*r The*p man took Jesus at his word and departed.
While he was still on the way, his servants met him with the news that his boy was living.
When he inquired as to the time when his son got better, they said to him, “Yesterday, at one in the afternoon, the fever left him.”
Then*p the father realized that this was the exact time at which Jesus had said to him, “Your*r son*r will*r live.”*r So he and his whole household believed.
This*p was the second sign Jesus performed after coming from Judea to Galilee.
John 5
The Healing at the Pool
Some*p time later, Jesus went up to Jerusalem for one of the Jewish festivals.
Now there is in Jerusalem near the Sheep Gate a pool, which in Aramaic is called Bethesda and which is surrounded by five covered colonnades.
Here a great number of disabled people used to lie—the blind, the lame, the paralyzed.
One who was there had been an invalid for thirty-eight years.
When Jesus saw him lying there and learned that he had been in this condition for a long time, he asked him, “Do*r you*r want*r to*r get*r well?”*r
“Sir,”*p the invalid replied, “I have no one to help me into the pool when the water is stirred. While I am trying to get in, someone else goes down ahead of me.”
Then*p Jesus said to him, “Get*r up!*r Pick*r up*r your*r mat*r and*r walk.”*r
At once the man was cured; he picked up his mat and walked. The*p day on which this took place was a Sabbath,
and so the Jewish leaders said to the man who had been healed, “It is the Sabbath; the law forbids you to carry your mat.”
But*p he replied, “The man who made me well said to me, ‘Pick*r up*r your*r mat*r and*r walk.’”*r
So*p they asked him, “Who is this fellow who told you to pick it up and walk?”
The*p man who was healed had no idea who it was, for Jesus had slipped away into the crowd that was there.
Later*p Jesus found him at the temple and said to him, “See,*r you*r are*r well*r again.*r Stop*r sinning*r or*r something*r worse*r may*r happen*r to*r you.”*r
The man went away and told the Jewish leaders that it was Jesus who had made him well.
The Authority of the Son
So,*p because Jesus was doing these things on the Sabbath, the Jewish leaders began to persecute him.
In his defense Jesus said to them, “My*r Father*r is*r always*r at*r his*r work*r to*r this*r very*r day,*r and*r I*r too*r am*r working.”*r
For this reason they tried all the more to kill him; not only was he breaking the Sabbath, but he was even calling God his own Father, making himself equal with God.

Jesus*p gave them this answer: “Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r the*r Son*r can*r do*r nothing*r by*r himself;*r he*r can*r do*r only*r what*r he*r sees*r his*r Father*r doing,*r because*r whatever*r the*r Father*r does*r the*r Son*r also*r does.*r
For*r the*r Father*r loves*r the*r Son*r and*r shows*r him*r all*r he*r does.*r Yes,*r and*r he*r will*r show*r him*r even*r greater*r works*r than*r these,*r so*r that*r you*r will*r be*r amazed.*r
For*r just*r as*r the*r Father*r raises*r the*r dead*r and*r gives*r them*r life,*r even*r so*r the*r Son*r gives*r life*r to*r whom*r he*r is*r pleased*r to*r give*r it.*r
Moreover,*r the*r Father*r judges*r no*r one,*r but*r has*r entrusted*r all*r judgment*r to*r the*r Son,*r
that*r all*r may*r honor*r the*r Son*r just*r as*r they*r honor*r the*r Father.*r Whoever*r does*r not*r honor*r the*r Son*r does*r not*r honor*r the*r Father,*r who*r sent*r him.*r

“Very*rp truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r whoever*r hears*r my*r word*r and*r believes*r him*r who*r sent*r me*r has*r eternal*r life*r and*r will*r not*r be*r judged*r but*r has*r crossed*r over*r from*r death*r to*r life.*r

Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r a*r time*r is*r coming*r and*r has*r now*r come*r when*r the*r dead*r will*r hear*r the*r voice*r of*r the*r Son*r of*r God*r and*r those*r who*r hear*r will*r live.*r
For*r as*r the*r Father*r has*r life*r in*r himself,*r so*r he*r has*r granted*r the*r Son*r also*r to*r have*r life*r in*r himself.*r
And*r he*r has*r given*r him*r authority*r to*r judge*r because*r he*r is*r the*r Son*r of*r Man.*r
“Do*rp not*r be*r amazed*r at*r this,*r for*r a*r time*r is*r coming*r when*r all*r who*r are*r in*r their*r graves*r will*r hear*r his*r voice*r
and*r come*r out—those*r who*r have*r done*r what*r is*r good*r will*r rise*r to*r live,*r and*r those*r who*r have*r done*r what*r is*r evil*r will*r rise*r to*r be*r condemned.*r
By*r myself*r I*r can*r do*r nothing;*r I*r judge*r only*r as*r I*r hear,*r and*r my*r judgment*r is*r just,*r for*r I*r seek*r not*r to*r please*r myself*r but*r him*r who*r sent*r me.*r
Testimonies About Jesus
“If*rp I*r testify*r about*r myself,*r my*r testimony*r is*r not*r true.*r
There*r is*r another*r who*r testifies*r in*r my*r favor,*r and*r I*r know*r that*r his*r testimony*r about*r me*r is*r true.*r
“You*rp have*r sent*r to*r John*r and*r he*r has*r testified*r to*r the*r truth.*r
Not*r that*r I*r accept*r human*r testimony;*r but*r I*r mention*r it*r that*r you*r may*r be*r saved.*r
John*r was*r a*r lamp*r that*r burned*r and*r gave*r light,*r and*r you*r chose*r for*r a*r time*r to*r enjoy*r his*r light.*r

“I*rp have*r testimony*r weightier*r than*r that*r of*r John.*r For*r the*r works*r that*r the*r Father*r has*r given*r me*r to*r finish—the*r very*r works*r that*r I*r am*r doing—testify*r that*r the*r Father*r has*r sent*r me.*r
And*r the*r Father*r who*r sent*r me*r has*r himself*r testified*r concerning*r me.*r You*r have*r never*r heard*r his*r voice*r nor*r seen*r his*r form,*r
nor*r does*r his*r word*r dwell*r in*r you,*r for*r you*r do*r not*r believe*r the*r one*r he*r sent.*r
You*r study*r the*r Scriptures*r diligently*r because*r you*r think*r that*r in*r them*r you*r have*r eternal*r life.*r These*r are*r the*r very*r Scriptures*r that*r testify*r about*r me,*r
